newsitem.title: USA: CBOE begins trading new S&P 500 index put warrants.
newsitem.headline: CBOE begins trading new S&P 500 index put warrants.

text.p: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said Thursday it began trading new put warrants on the S&P 500 stock index that expire on November 20, 1997.

The warrants, issued by the International Finance Corp, a subsidiary of the World Bank, have a strike price of 743.95, but the strike price will be reset in three months if the index is above that level.
The S&P 500 was trading at around 742, down two points, at 1140 CST (1740 GMT) Thursday.
Oppenheimer & Co and EVEREN Securities underwrote the offering of 1.25 million capitalized warrants, called International Finance Corp S&P 500 Index Bear Market Warrants.
The warrants are American style, meaning they can be exercised at any time up to expiration.
At 1140 CST (1740 GMT), the warrants were trading at 3-3/4 on volume of 38,500.

OTA Limited Partnership is the designated primary market maker for the warrants, which trade during normal stock market hours of 0830 to 1500 CST (1430 to 2100 GMT). --Derivatives desk, 312 408 8750/Email: derivatives@reuters.com
